of Dome". For, resembling an exconvict rather than an exclusive,
Burt provided such a sight last Saturday as to completely enthrall the
hundred-odd students in the dormitory and set them roaring with glee.
And that was only his first-night
audience.
Ace Of Spades Bad Luck

As to how this business came
about, the answer is that Burt Cannon lost his locks upon the turn of
a card. It was a high-finance gamble, between Burt and John Canning, for the high card, with the
other man's hair as the prize. Cannon drew the Ace of Spades, and
razors were brought into play on
Cannon's head. A cup was placed
on the top of his skull, and all the
surrounding hair removed. Then
this topknot was shaped to a triangle, and the picture was complete.
But Burt disapproved of his resemblance to a Hottentot, and later
removed the remaining tuft.
Many a person has lost his shirt
on a gamble, but Burt Cannon has
the distinguished honor of being
the only one ever to lose his hair.

Friday, January 19, 1934

They've Cooked Up An Excuse
The explanations anent the athletic department's policy for next year which the pressure of
student protest has elicited from Coach Van Orman have left us with a feeling of dissatisfaction.
It's a feeling much akin to that experienced by an
army which has besieged a city for months and,
upon finally breaking through, discovered that the
enemy has decamped with all the spoil. These
athletics boys are slippery and elusive; but there's
some consolation in the fact that we scared them
into showing their real hand.
The hand is this: they have to be continually
ridden by the students before they can be depended upon to do their jobs efficiently. One of
the members of the Athletic Council, a high University official, said a very significant thing when
he recommended to the 0. D. K. committee, which
recently protested before the Council that the
captains and managers of the teams were the logical ones to complain when the coach and financial
manager neglected to supply enough equipment
and coaching talent. It seems to show the attitude
of the authorities — that continual prodding is
the only way to secure decent treatment from the
athletic department.

But It's Strikingly Flimsy
But though the officials have escaped the terrain which we beseiged they have very naively
left themselves in open ground and entirely defenseless before some of our more important
charges. They spiel off glibly that so many uniforms have been ordered here, so much money
appropriated there, that necessary economies forced
the dropping of Mallonee as assistant coach. But
we want to know why the money wasn't spent before? The money was available last year and yet
it wasn't spent. How do we know that the same
thing won't happen next year? Is it an indication
of competence on the part of an athletic administration which has to be dragged by the nose to do
the obvious? We believe emphatically that it is
not. The squirming of the department under the
cross-fire which has afflicted it for the past three
weeks is to us too much of an admission of guilt.
Its almost frenzied efforts to prove that it is doing what is needful have left us skeptical of its
power of self-motivation after the pressure is
removed. The clam-like nature of its attitude toward every decent question we ask is becoming
It is not apparent that there is any need for
economies such as were introduced last year,
namely, the cutting of Mallonee and of training
table. Particularly when nearly $500 of the appropriation was not spent and when we are supporting a coach on a vastly disproportionate salary.
Just what sort of reasoning, we wonder, does the
athletic department think we follow? The gaping
holes in its defense would accomodate the coachand-four of the old adage.

So It Won't Do
So far, gentlemen, you haven't come across
with anything that amounts to anything. We'll
have to insist on more concrete evidence of good
intentions. If we don't get it now we may never
get it, because there's no assurance that there will
always be the freedom of criticism which we experience at present nor the coincidence of cit cumstances which makes this a particularly appropriate time to demand an accounting.

Soothing Prospect
Writing editorials on campus problems, if we
may dignify our brawls as such, engenders a sort of
sour outlook on the goodness of humanity as an applied principle. But we see some redeeming feature;
at least somebody concurs with our ideas of good
sense. And who should it be but the freshman?
Motivated by some hitherto unfelt stimulus the
frosh have decided that it's well to lock to the
future, and so have decided that they will bolter
up their treasury so that when they reach seniorhood (that Valhalla of intellectual embryos—just
ask a senior), the class dues will be within reason.
It's a wise move to plan the frosh-soph dance; the
rewards will come later.
Additional evidence of good sense is the effort
to interject some semblance of coherence and direction to the annual banquet season fighting.
Last year we suggested an organized flag rush,

but a pants rush is just as good and probably
more interesting. There are some freshmen,
names given on request, whose souls would be
materially benefitted by a little workout after the
pants-rush detail is accomplished.

Rats!

Walt Disney's Pied Piper of Hamlin has nothing on Baltimore's local rat survey. However,
in the modern version of Browning's immortal
tale, only a small percentage of Baltimore's rats
are captured; and, as far as the Hopkins is concerned, the countless rodent denizens of the University
continue to gambol on the green in complete
security.
As an example of the small scale upon which
the hunting operations by the United States Quarantine Station at Curtis Bay are carried on in
Baltimore, only 300 rats were caught on a recent
peak day of the campaign now under way. But
in the face of this Dr. H. F. White, director of the
survey, has declared that "The showing thus far
is very gratifying and demonstrates quite expert
trapping by men with no experience."
Nevertheless, even though the scope of the survey's operations be increased, the rats of our campus will undoubtedly remain unmolested. With
this prospect in view, the suggestion has been
made that the National Student League insert a
plank in their platform demanding a governmental
board to execute an "anti-rat" movement, perhaps
similar to that now in use in France, where the
Paris police are directing a drive against rats.
There the Prefecture maintains a special service
of "deratization," which has been especially active
during the past year, having carried out anti-rat
offensives in 1,015 places in Paris and the suburbs.
But something must indeed be done here, for
rats abound on the campus. They are especially
numerous around Gilman Hall, and a student recently reported seeing one the size of a full-grown
muskrat, strolling across the road at the south end
of the automobile tunnel. And they abound around the
outside of Alumni Memorial Hall—"Great rats, small
rats, lean rats, scrawny rats, brown rats, black rats,
gray rats, tawny rats, grave old plodders, gay
young friskers, fathers, mothers, uncles, cousins,
cocking tails and pricking whiskers, and families
by tens and dozens."

S. A. C. fee for their wares, they will have all the
"indignant mothers" writing to THE NEWS-LETTER.
The staff has to write something, but don't give
them a chance to write stuff like that again.

Letters To The Editor
Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER:
Sir: According to Theodore Stern, president of
the S. A. C., and editor of the Hullabaloo, the stu
dents will not receive a copy of the yearbook unless they make an extra payment. This, despite
the fact that the S. A. C. card signed by Stern in
his official capacity says that the holder of the
card is to get, among other things, a copy of the
Hullabaloo "without further charge". That was
the legal agreement and is now being flagrantly
violated.
If it is true, as has been said, that the extra
payment is necessary because of funds frozen in
the Union Trust Company, then why were not plans
laid accordingly before the money was collected
from students at the beginning of this year? The
bank was closed in October; yet the Student Activities Council collected the ten dollars per student
and Stern signed each card, promising them something which, it is now claimed, cannot be supplied.
If our extra-curricular organization leaders did not
know how much money would be needed, then
they are guilty of gross inefficiency; and if they
knew that they would be short money and yet
went ahead with the selling of the compulsory
activities cards, they are guilty of taking'money
under false pretenses.
Anyone who criticises is immediately
squelched by being asked for his method of unsnarling the tangle. I doubt whether I can suggest a satisfactory solution, partly because I am
unacquainted with the complexities of S. A. C.
finances.
The Activities Council got themselves in the
mess; let them extricate themselves without crying
to the school for sympathy and attempting to
cover over their mistake by an extra levy on the
student body.
S. R.

OTHER considerations which
arise are also enumerated by the
city paper. The first, it points out,
is "that any committee member or
administrative official who tries to
interpret or evaluate another man's
conscience is undertaking a difficult,
if not impossible, task."

Politics At Yale
(Reprinted from "The Nation")

THE students of Yale University are
being introduced to public affairs by
way of the picket line and a policeman's
club, and at least some of them do not
at all like what they find. Lawrence
Hill and William Gordon, members of
the Yale chapter of the National Student League, were arrested during the
first part of December for standing in
the picket line during the Kirschner
foundry strike in New Haven.
Immediately after the arrests the Yale
Daily News gave the matter wide publicity, and two groups of students were
organized to protest to the Mayor. The
first group was refused admittance. The
second was permitted to send a delegation of three as spokesmen to His Honor,
whereupon they were harangued with a
blast against communism. A large number of students attempted to be present
at the trials, but the police cleared the
courtroom of everyone not directly connected with the cases.
IT IS POINTED out by persons interested in the controversy that many
of the students taking part in the various
protests had never demonstrated in anything but a football rally before. The
arrests, moreover, followed not only the
picketing but articles in the Yale Daily
News describing conditions in the Kirschner plant. Dean Clarence Mendel is
quoted as saying: "Yale college authorities are entirely out of sympathy with
the interference of students in New
Haven affairs about which they are uninformed . . . The college will not
encourage the students in any extra-legal
attempts to determine the right or wrong
of any local problems."
SOMEBODY should inform the dean
that picketing has been declared legal by
no less a tribunal than the Supreme Court
of the United States; there was, therefore, nothing extra-legal in the action of
the students, unless it is illegal to print
articles describing conditions in a particular factory. If the articles are unfavorable and untrue, there are still libel
laws to which the factory owners may
have recourse. If they are true, there is
every reason for college students to take
an interest in them and in strikes generally.
There is something most unseemly in
the attitude of a college ocer who deliberately opposes, and attempts to persuade the undergraduates in his charge to
oppose, student criticism of local industrial conditions. Yale is doubtless offering courses in sociology and economics.
Where is there a better place for a direct application of the theories taught in
the classroom than in the town in which
the college is situated?

THE third consideration is
"whether any student gets much that
is worthwhile out of a course that
he is forced to take against his will."
The editorial ends by saying, "A
young man who risks expulsion in
such a situation seems to us to enjoy a preponderance of evidence on
the side of his sincerity."

SAYS LIVING TODAY Prodigal Son Returns, Unfolds
MORE FASCINATING Sunny And Not-So-Sunny South
THAN IN PAST ERA Dr. Mitchell Describes To Classes Beauty Of Southern
Sherwood Eddy, Noted Author, Addresses Combined Meeting
Addressing a combined meeting
of the Y. M. C. A. cabinet and the
Freshman Commission on Tuesday
night, Sherwood Eddy, lecturer and
author, stated that "Liberty without
justice and justice without liberty
are not good enough."
He believed that while it might
have been fascinating to live during the Italian Renaissance, the
French Revolution, the American
Revolution, or the Russian Revolution, it is far more interesting to be
alive today when a stupenduous
transition is taking place also.
New Epoch

The new epoch which students
will help bring about Mr. Eddy expected to embody Greek culture, Roman law and order, Hebrew moral
and spiritual insight, scientific
achievement for the production of
a material basis of life for all, and a
social movement for justice and the
more universal sharing of privilege.
From this point of view, the
speaker commented on both the
Russian and the American experiments. He expressed a disinclination to live under the Soviets because of its denial of liberty, its
violence and compulsion involving
perpetual revolution and a restriction of emigration, and its dogmatic
atheism. At the same time he admitted that an attempt to abolish unemployment, injustice, and poverty
were "amazingly good things."
Underdog Helped

With regard to the NRA and the
AAA, Mr. Eddy believed that the
Roosevelt program was out to help
the underdog. A large number of
outspoken senators with whom he
had chatted believed the President
would eventually be driven to the
left, he said.

of Dome". For, resembling an exconvict rather than an exclusive,
Burt provided such a sight last Saturday as to completely enthrall the
hundred-odd students in the dormitory and set them roaring with glee.
And that was only his first-night
audience.
Ace Of Spades Bad Luck

As to how this business came
about, the answer is that Burt Cannon lost his locks upon the turn of
a card. It was a high-finance gamble, between Burt and John Canning, for the high card, with the
other man's hair as the prize. Cannon drew the Ace of Spades, and
razors were brought into play on
Cannon's head. A cup was placed
on the top of his skull, and all the
surrounding hair removed. Then
this topknot was shaped to a triangle, and the picture was complete.
But Burt disapproved of his resemblance to a Hottentot, and later
removed the remaining tuft.
Many a person has lost his shirt
on a gamble, but Burt Cannon has
the distinguished honor of being
the only one ever to lose his hair.

Friday, January 19, 1934

They've Cooked Up An Excuse
The explanations anent the athletic department's policy for next year which the pressure of
student protest has elicited from Coach Van Orman have left us with a feeling of dissatisfaction.
It's a feeling much akin to that experienced by an
army which has besieged a city for months and,
upon finally breaking through, discovered that the
enemy has decamped with all the spoil. These
athletics boys are slippery and elusive; but there's
some consolation in the fact that we scared them
into showing their real hand.
The hand is this: they have to be continually
ridden by the students before they can be depended upon to do their jobs efficiently. One of
the members of the Athletic Council, a high University official, said a very significant thing when
he recommended to the 0. D. K. committee, which
recently protested before the Council that the
captains and managers of the teams were the logical ones to complain when the coach and financial
manager neglected to supply enough equipment
and coaching talent. It seems to show the attitude
of the authorities — that continual prodding is
the only way to secure decent treatment from the
athletic department.

But It's Strikingly Flimsy
But though the officials have escaped the terrain which we beseiged they have very naively
left themselves in open ground and entirely defenseless before some of our more important
charges. They spiel off glibly that so many uniforms have been ordered here, so much money
appropriated there, that necessary economies forced
the dropping of Mallonee as assistant coach. But
we want to know why the money wasn't spent before? The money was available last year and yet
it wasn't spent. How do we know that the same
thing won't happen next year? Is it an indication
of competence on the part of an athletic administration which has to be dragged by the nose to do
the obvious? We believe emphatically that it is
not. The squirming of the department under the
cross-fire which has afflicted it for the past three
weeks is to us too much of an admission of guilt.
Its almost frenzied efforts to prove that it is doing what is needful have left us skeptical of its
power of self-motivation after the pressure is
removed. The clam-like nature of its attitude toward every decent question we ask is becoming
It is not apparent that there is any need for
economies such as were introduced last year,
namely, the cutting of Mallonee and of training
table. Particularly when nearly $500 of the appropriation was not spent and when we are supporting a coach on a vastly disproportionate salary.
Just what sort of reasoning, we wonder, does the
athletic department think we follow? The gaping
holes in its defense would accomodate the coachand-four of the old adage.

So It Won't Do
So far, gentlemen, you haven't come across
with anything that amounts to anything. We'll
have to insist on more concrete evidence of good
intentions. If we don't get it now we may never
get it, because there's no assurance that there will
always be the freedom of criticism which we experience at present nor the coincidence of cit cumstances which makes this a particularly appropriate time to demand an accounting.

Soothing Prospect
Writing editorials on campus problems, if we
may dignify our brawls as such, engenders a sort of
sour outlook on the goodness of humanity as an applied principle. But we see some redeeming feature;
at least somebody concurs with our ideas of good
sense. And who should it be but the freshman?
Motivated by some hitherto unfelt stimulus the
frosh have decided that it's well to lock to the
future, and so have decided that they will bolter
up their treasury so that when they reach seniorhood (that Valhalla of intellectual embryos—just
ask a senior), the class dues will be within reason.
It's a wise move to plan the frosh-soph dance; the
rewards will come later.
Additional evidence of good sense is the effort
to interject some semblance of coherence and direction to the annual banquet season fighting.
Last year we suggested an organized flag rush,

but a pants rush is just as good and probably
more interesting. There are some freshmen,
names given on request, whose souls would be
materially benefitted by a little workout after the
pants-rush detail is accomplished.

Ah9

Rats!

Walt Disney's Pied Piper of Hamlin has nothing on Baltimore's local rat survey. However,
in the modern version of Browning's immortal
tale, only a small percentage of Baltimore's rats
are captured; and, as far as the Hopkins is concerned, the countless rodent denizens of the University
continue to gambol on the green in complete
security.
As an example of the small scale upon which
the hunting operations by the United States Quarantine Station at Curtis Bay are carried on in
Baltimore, only 300 rats were caught on a recent
peak day of the campaign now under way. But
in the face of this Dr. H. F. White, director of the
survey, has declared that "The showing thus far
is very gratifying and demonstrates quite expert
trapping by men with no experience."
Nevertheless, even though the scope of the survey's operations be increased, the rats of our campus will undoubtedly remain unmolested. With
this prospect in view, the suggestion has been
made that the National Student League insert a
plank in their platform demanding a governmental
board to execute an "anti-rat" movement, perhaps
similar to that now in use in France, where the
Paris police are directing a drive against rats.
There the Prefecture maintains a special service
of "deratization," which has been especially active
during the past year, having carried out anti-rat
offensives in 1,015 places in Paris and the suburbs.
But something must indeed be done here, for
rats abound on the campus. They are especially
numerous around Gilman Hall, and a student recently reported seeing one the size of a full-grown
muskrat, strolling across the road at the south end
of the automobile tunnel. And they abound around the
outside of Alumni Memorial Hall—"Great rats, small
rats, lean rats, scrawny rats, brown rats, black rats,
gray rats, tawny rats, grave old plodders, gay
young friskers, fathers, mothers, uncles, cousins,
cocking tails and pricking whiskers, and families
by tens and dozens."

Campus Brevities
Until activities stop charging prices above the

Letters To The Editor
Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER:
Sir: According to Theodore Stern, president of
the S. A. C., and editor of the Hullabaloo, the stu
dents will not receive a copy of the yearbook unless they make an extra payment. This, despite
the fact that the S. A. C. card signed by Stern in
his official capacity says that the holder of the
card is to get, among other things, a copy of the
Hullabaloo "without further charge". That was
the legal agreement and is now being flagrantly
violated.
If it is true, as has been said, that the extra
payment is necessary because of funds frozen in
the Union Trust Company, then why were not plans
laid accordingly before the money was collected
from students at the beginning of this year? The
bank was closed in October; yet the Student Activities Council collected the ten dollars per student
and Stern signed each card, promising them something which, it is now claimed, cannot be supplied.
If our extra-curricular organization leaders did not
know how much money would be needed, then
they are guilty of gross inefficiency; and if they
knew that they would be short money and yet
went ahead with the selling of the compulsory
activities cards, they are guilty of taking'money
under false pretenses.
Anyone who criticises is immediately
squelched by being asked for his method of unsnarling the tangle. I doubt whether I can suggest a satisfactory solution, partly because I am
unacquainted with the complexities of S. A. C.
finances.
The Activities Council got themselves in the
mess; let them extricate themselves without crying
to the school for sympathy and attempting to
cover over their mistake by an extra levy on the
student body.
S. R.

Politics At Yale
(Reprinted from "The Nation")

THE students of Yale University are
being introduced to public affairs by
way of the picket line and a policeman's
club, and at least some of them do not
at all like what they find. Lawrence
Hill and William Gordon, members of
the Yale chapter of the National Student League, were arrested during the
first part of December for standing in
the picket line during the Kirschner
foundry strike in New Haven.
Immediately after the arrests the Yale
Daily News gave the matter wide publicity, and two groups of students were
organized to protest to the Mayor. The
first group was refused admittance. The
second was permitted to send a delegation of three as spokesmen to His Honor,
whereupon they were harangued with a
blast against communism. A large number of students attempted to be present
at the trials, but the police cleared the
courtroom of everyone not directly connected with the cases.
IT IS POINTED out by persons interested in the controversy that many
of the students taking part in the various
protests had never demonstrated in anything but a football rally before. The
arrests, moreover, followed not only the
picketing but articles in the Yale Daily
News describing conditions in the Kirschner plant. Dean Clarence Mendel is
quoted as saying: "Yale college authorities are entirely out of sympathy with
the interference of students in New
Haven affairs about which they are uninformed . . . The college will not
encourage the students in any extra-legal
attempts to determine the right or wrong
of any local problems."
SOMEBODY should inform the dean
that picketing has been declared legal by
no less a tribunal than the Supreme Court
of the United States; there was, therefore, nothing extra-legal in the action of
the students, unless it is illegal to print
articles describing conditions in a particular factory. If the articles are unfavorable and untrue, there are still libel
laws to which the factory owners may
have recourse. If they are true, there is
every reason for college students to take
an interest in them and in strikes generally.
There is something most unseemly in
the attitude of a college ocer who deliberately opposes, and attempts to persuade the undergraduates in his charge to
oppose, student criticism of local industrial conditions. Yale is doubtless offering courses in sociology and economics.
Where is there a better place for a direct application of the theories taught in
the classroom than in the town in which
the college is situated?

THE third consideration is
"whether any student gets much that
is worthwhile out of a course that
he is forced to take against his will."
The editorial ends by saying, "A
young man who risks expulsion in
such a situation seems to us to enjoy a preponderance of evidence on
the side of his sincerity."

MORE FASCINATING Sunny And Not-So-Sunny South
THAN IN PAST ERA Dr. Mitchell Describes To Classes Beauty Of Southern
Sherwood Eddy, Noted Author, Addresses Combined Meeting
Addressing a combined meeting
of the Y. M. C. A. cabinet and the
Freshman Commission on Tuesday
night, Sherwood Eddy, lecturer and
author, stated that "Liberty without
justice and justice without liberty
are not good enough."
He believed that while it might
have been fascinating to live during the Italian Renaissance, the
French Revolution, the American
Revolution, or the Russian Revolution, it is far more interesting to be
alive today when a stupenduous
transition is taking place also.
New Epoch

The new epoch which students
will help bring about Mr. Eddy expected to embody Greek culture, Roman law and order, Hebrew moral
and spiritual insight, scientific
achievement for the production of
a material basis of life for all, and a
social movement for justice and the
more universal sharing of privilege.
From this point of view, the
speaker commented on both the
Russian and the American experiments. He expressed a disinclination to live under the Soviets because of its denial of liberty, its
violence and compulsion involving
perpetual revolution and a restriction of emigration, and its dogmatic
atheism. At the same time he admitted that an attempt to abolish unemployment, injustice, and poverty
were "amazingly good things."
Underdog Helped

With regard to the NRA and the
AAA, Mr. Eddy believed that the
Roosevelt program was out to help
the underdog. A large number of
outspoken senators with whom he
had chatted believed the President
would eventually be driven to the
left, he said.
